title: Introduction to Digital Humanities
text:
Hands-on Experience: Text Analysis
Let’s try a simple text analysis using R!


Code
# Load required libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(tidytext)

# Sample text (first paragraph of "Pride and Prejudice")
text <- "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife. However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his first entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds of the surrounding families, that he is considered the rightful property of some one or other of their daughters."

# Tokenize the text
words <- tibble(text = text) %>%
  unnest_tokens(word, text)

# Count word frequencies
word_freq <- words %>%
  count(word, sort = TRUE) %>%
  filter(!word %in% stop_words$word)

# Display top 10 words
head(word_freq, 10)




# A tibble: 10 × 2
   word             n
   <chr>        <int>
 1 truth            2
 2 acknowledged     1
 3 considered       1
 4 daughters        1
 5 entering         1
 6 families         1
 7 feelings         1
 8 fixed            1
 9 fortune          1
10 minds            1


Code
# Create a simple bar plot
ggplot(head(word_freq, 10), aes(x = reorder(word, n), y = n)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Top 10 Words in Pride and Prejudice Excerpt",
       x = "Word", y = "Frequency")










What patterns do you notice in this analysis?

title: Introduction to Digital Humanities
text:
Digital Humanities (DH) is an area of scholarly activity at the intersection of computing and the disciplines of the humanities. It brings digital tools and methods to the study of the humanities with the recognition that the printed word is no longer the main medium for knowledge production and distribution.



Interdisciplinarity: DH combines methodologies from traditional humanities disciplines with tools provided by computing.
Data Analysis: Large-scale analysis of cultural data sets.
Visualization: Creating visual representations of humanities data.
Digital Preservation: Preserving cultural heritage through digital means.

In the next chapters, we’ll dive deeper into these concepts and start exploring practical applications.

title: Preface
text:
This is the textbook for the course Introduction to Digital Humanities taught by Meng Liu, at the School of English and International Studies, Beijing Foreign Studies University.
Introduction to Digital Humanities explores the intersection of humanities scholarship and digital methodologies. Students will learn how computational techniques can enhance humanities research, covering key concepts in digital humanities, modern R programming, and various analytical methods including quantitative text analysis, topic modeling, sentiment analysis, and social network analysis. Through hands-on application of digital tools to humanities data, students will develop both technical skills and critical thinking abilities. The course progresses from foundational programming to advanced analytical techniques, concluding with discussions on ethics and AI in humanities scholarship. By the end of the course, students will be equipped with a versatile toolkit for innovative, data-driven humanities research, suitable for those seeking to expand their methodological approach to cultural studies.
The content of the book is updated on a regular basis as the course progresses.

title: Syllabus
text:
🚀 Ground Rules






🫡 Ground Rules



Please adhere to these core principles throughout the course:



Be Open-Minded

Approach new concepts and methods without preconceptions.
Set aside any stereotypes or misconceptions about digital technologies in humanities.
Remain receptive to diverse perspectives and unconventional ideas.



Embrace Frustration as Progress

Understand that frustration is a normal part of the learning process.
View challenges as opportunities for growth rather than obstacles.
Give yourself time to work through difficult concepts or technical issues.



Own Your Learning

Take responsibility for your learning in this course.
Actively seek out resources and ask questions when you need help.
Set personal learning goals and work consistently towards achieving them.



Don’t Fool Yourself

Be honest about your understanding and progress.
Acknowledge your limitations and areas for improvement.
Critically examine your assumptions and conclusions.







Remember



By following these principles, you’ll create a positive learning experience for yourself and contribute to a supportive classroom environment for everyone.
